1 Introduction

The work in this report was undertaken as a capstone project at the Institute for Applied Computational Science (IACS) at Harvard University, addressing a pertinent and complex issue in agricultural economics - the optimization of commodity pricing for farmers. Under the advisory guidance of Dr. Pavlos Protopapas, and in collaboration with Senecal Capital, we embarked on a journey to use statistical modeling and machine learning techniques to maximize farm profitability.

1.1 Problem Statement

Agriculture, notably grain farming, forms the backbone of many rural economies. Despite advancements in farming methods and technologies, grain farmers often face a critical economic dilemma: determining the optimal time to sell their produce to maximize profitability. The quandary arises due to the highly volatile nature of grain prices, which are influenced by a myriad of factors ranging from local weather conditions and pest infestations to global market trends and geopolitical events.

Grain prices fluctuate substantially throughout the year, affected by seasonal patterns of supply and demand. For instance, prices often dip during the harvest season when the supply is abundant and rise during off-season periods when the supply is limited. However, these seasonal fluctuations are superimposed on longer-term trends and shorter-term price shocks triggered by unexpected events. The complex interplay of these factors can lead to significant price differences even among grain elevators in the same region, thereby further complicating the farmers’ decision-making process.

Farmers, therefore, need a mechanism that can help them navigate these price fluctuations and guide their sales decisions. This is not just a matter of selecting the right time to sell; it is also about choosing the right place. With thousands of grain elevators dispersed across various states, each with its unique pricing patterns, farmers need to identify not only when but also where they could get the best price for their produce.

Moreover, occasional pricing abnormalities may present lucrative opportunities for farmers. However, detecting such abnormalities requires analyzing vast amounts of data and discerning subtle patterns—a task that is virtually impossible without the aid of sophisticated data analytics tools.

1.2 Objectives

Our primary objective is to develop a robust, cloud-based framework capable of discerning periods of low or high grain prices based on historical data and geographical coordinates. This framework, designed to evaluate basis price fluctuations across thousands of grain elevators in the United States, aims to aid farmers in identifying pricing abnormalities and making data-driven sales decisions.

1.3 Scope

The framework, built on historical prices and geographical coordinates, facilitates the assessment of basis price fluctuations of thousands of grain elevators dispersed across various states. It is further designed to identify abnormalities that may present lucrative opportunities for farmers. The employed methodology emulates diffusion on a two-dimensional manifold, a technique that has demonstrated proficiency in detecting pricing anomalies.

The hierarchical structure of the model considers temporal and spatial variables independently, allowing for nuanced and accurate predictions. Other standalone models, which we call SpaceTime models, effectively combine the temporal and spatial variables. Models such as RNNs, which are well-suited to pattern recognition in time-series data, and Gaussian processes, which offer robustness against overfitting and flexibility in modeling complex data, are of such kinds.

The proposed framework empowers farmers to make informed sales decisions derived from an ensemble of models. The ensemble approach capitalizes on the strengths of individual models, enhances overall predictive accuracy, and decreases the risk of selecting an under-performing model.

By advancing our collective knowledge in statistical and machine learning applications in agricultural pricing, we stand to contribute significantly to the broader discourse on data-driven strategies for agricultural profitability.

1.4 Significance

The project’s significance extends beyond its immediate academic implications. It represents an intersection of agricultural economics, machine learning, and cloud computing, with potential widespread impacts on the agricultural industry. By enabling farmers to optimize their pricing strategies and maximize profitability, the project could contribute to broader economic stability and sustainability in the farming sector.

1.5 Organization of the Report

This report is structured into several key sections. After this introduction, we delve into the technical details of the machine learning models and techniques employed, followed by a comprehensive discussion of the design and operation of the cloud-based framework. Subsequent sections present our findings, discuss their implications, and suggest potential directions for future research and development. By comprehensively covering the project’s complexities, this report also aims to serve as a guide for Senecal Capital staff, aiding in their ongoing efforts to refine and expand upon the current knowledge and tools. The information presented here should facilitate a deeper understanding of the project’s complexities and guide the team in its ongoing efforts to expand upon the current arsenal of knowledge and tools.

By blending academic rigor with practical relevance, we hope this project not only stands as a testament to our learning journey but also provides valuable insights for the advancement of agricultural economics.
